ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about research in fpga security
Insight into security concerns for FPGA cloud services, and some Verilog.
Cybersecurity regarding FPGA cloud computing infrastructures and some verilog.

Learned a bit about FPGAs, cloud computing, and Verilog simulation. I gained a big picture idea of how cloud computing with FPGAs is carried out today, including the challenges and responsibilities of the end users, cloud providers, and hardware manufacturers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the material is interesting but the professor was absent for much of the course. He cancelled many classes last minute and failed to assign homework and projects like he promised, resulting in a chaotic class experience. We never got grades or feedback for the few assignments we did do. It was difficult to stay engaged with the material and actually learn anything with such inconsistent instruction.

The course talked a lot about Verilog at the beginning but had no real assignments on Verilog. Similarly, we never got to access an actual FPGA board, only discussed the potential security issues with certain configurations. Although I found the topics interesting, the course was not super organized and the plan changed many times.
I wish you learned more verilog and did more hands on programming.

Not many strengths in the current state. The weekly research paper reading assignments were very dry as the content was not at all geared towards an undergraduate audience, although the papers did a good job of ground the course content in modern practices and the latest developments in the field of cloud computing with FPGAs. The lectures attempt to teaching code through slides which ends up making the entire semester incredibly unengaging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you're specifically interested in security for cloud FPGAs. Otherwise, you're probably better off taking something else.
If you are interested in cybersecurity, yes. If you want to learn FPGA, no.

In its current state, where Professor Szefer clearly has a host of commitments that require his attention ahead of this course, I would absolutely recommend NOT taking this course. Your learning will suffer as most of the things listed in the course description were not effectively addressed. If you are expecting to learn Verilog in this course, look elsewhere: the first time the students themselves were asked to attempt Verilog was on the midterm, and the next was the final project. Throughout the semester, the already sparse project was stripped even more as students simply did not possess the technical understanding to carry out an actually interesting project. It would be a better use of your time to get a Basys 3 Artix-7 FPGA board and follow youtube tutorials to learn about FPGAs than enrolling in this course.
